title: 110_hr3385
content:
The "National Homelessness Task Force Act of 2007" establishes a task force in the legislative branch known as the "National Homelessness Task Force" with specific duties. The Task Force, in consultation with relevant Federal agencies, will review reports on homelessness, evaluate existing programs, assess cost-effectiveness, and analyze coordination with State and local entities. The Task Force will analyze options and make recommendations to improve Federal programs addressing homelessness, enhance State and local shelter programs, and establish an outreach program for homeless individuals to access resources. The Task Force aims to improve coordination between agencies dealing with homelessness and develop methods to assist homeless individuals with mental illnesses and expand affordable housing options for chronically homeless individuals and those below the poverty line. The Task Force aims to establish a system for homeless individuals to access employment and job-training programs to minimize the time they remain homeless. The Task Force focuses on creating opportunities for homeless individuals to access employment and job-training programs. SEC. 4 outlines the membership requirements. The Task Force, composed of up to 10 members, is appointed by the House Committee on Financial Services and the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs within 90 days of the Act's enactment. TF members are selected from various agencies, organizations, and institutions based on qualifications to perform Task functions. The Task Force, consisting of up to 10 members, is appointed by specific committees based on their qualifications in housing or economic development. TF members serve without compensation but receive travel expenses. The Task Force has 2 Chairpersons chosen by leaders from the Senate and House of Representatives. SEC. 5. STAFF OF THE TASK FORCE AND EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS.

(a) Staff.--The Chairpersons may appoint 3 to 6 individuals as personnel and set their pay.
(b) Experts and Consultants.--The Chairpersons can hire temporary services at specified rates.
(c) Staff of Federal Agencies.--Federal agencies can provide personnel to assist the Task Force.

SEC. 6. POWERS. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Task Force members and agents can take actions authorized by the Task Force. They can obtain official data from Federal departments and agencies and use the United States mails. SEC. 7. REPORTS.

(a) Initial Report - Within 3 months of appointing TF members, a report on Task Force duties will be submitted to Congress.

(b) Final Report - Within 12 months of appointing TF members, a report on Task Force activities, long-term goals, and strategies to reduce homelessness will be submitted to Congress.

SEC. 8. TERMINATION - The Task Force will end 10 days after submitting the final report.

SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. For the purposes of this Act, "affordable housing" includes properties under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 and single-room occupancy units. A "chronically homeless individual" is an unaccompanied, disabled person who has been homeless for at least 1 year or 4 episodes in the past 3 years. A "disabling condition" refers to substance use disorder, mental illness, developmental disability, or chronic physical illness. The term "homeless individual" is defined in section 103 of the McKinney-Vento Act. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act is set at $2,000,000.
